WhyEN: To a person/recipient is commonly expressed with “at” (not “i”).
Destination/place you go or send into → “i”.
Going to a place → “i” + soft mutation (Caerdydd → Gaerdydd).
WhyCY: Mynd i le → “i” + treiglad meddal (Caerdydd → Gaerdydd).

WhyEN: Appointments/people as a target often take “at”.
WhyCY: At apwyntiad/person fel targed, mae “at” yn gyffredin.

WhyEN: Talking to a person often uses “at”.

WhyCY: Tarddiad/ffynhonnell → “o”. (Does dim newid i Abertawe yma.)

PromptEN: My keys are on the table.
I’ll see you before the concert.

WhyCY: Ar ôl o ran amser → “ar ôl”.
Ar ôl o ran amser → “ar ôl”.

PromptEN: Park in front of the house.
The garden is behind the house.

WhyEN: “with” in the sense of ‘including’ often uses “gyda”.
With feelings/conditions, Welsh often uses inflected “ar”: arna i.
WhyCY: Gyda chyflwr/teimlad, defnyddir “ar” cyfunol: arna i.

WhyEN: Hunger/need commonly uses “ar” inflected with pronouns.
WhyCY: Mae eisiau/newyn yn aml gyda “ar” cyfunol.

WhyEN: Some experiences use “ar” inflected: arni hi.
WhyCY: Mae rhai profiadau gyda “ar” cyfunol: arni hi.

PromptEN: She heard it through a friend.
It was done by the teacher.

WhyCY: Wrth fan/lle (gerllaw) yn aml → “wrth” (yn dibynnu ar y cyd-destun).

PromptEN: Stay with me (at my place / near me).
The book is on the table.
